instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.PPBUS_G3: What is PPBUS_G3? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H. When you see PPBUS_G3, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.
definitions.PP_BUS: What is PP_BUS? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H When you see PP_BUS, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..

threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> first.
Be sure to use 85W Magsafe 2 charger.

Post Y5110 DC voltage, if not o-scope available.

threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS= 0V
Y5110 DC voltage ON PIN 1 IS 1.40V PIN 3 1,22 V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message: But is there more than one version of this logic board? Because the scheme is slightly different

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message:
There is no boardview available for 00138; can use 00163 instead, with some differences.
Be aware of schematics; X425G is for 00163 and X425 for 00138.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message: I downloaded 00163 and realized that there was no capacitor near SMC or <CAPACITOR>C3550</CAPACITOR> (on 00163 boardview that corresponds to reality) and it was short-circuited. Then while I was checking <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> I touched <CAPACITOR>C7102</CAPACITOR> with <CAPACITOR>C7116</CAPACITOR> and I had to replace <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, all as before but I have low insulation on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_BUS</SIGNAL> is now 3.29V. Do I need to replace SMC? Would 00163 possibly be fine?[ATTACH type="full"]60372[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message:
Post diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> power rail.
What voltages do you get on the board now?
Which is the exact symptom?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_BUS_G3</SIGNAL> = 3.30v
<SIGNAL>PP_BUS_G3</SIGNAL>= 12.23
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>= 0,831v
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>= 3,00v
Post diode mode <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>= 0,025

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message:
Dificil to understand why using these names for the first two lines.

"<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>= 0,831v"
That is bad enough; unless you've meant diode mode, not voltage.
REMEMBER, do NOT write the end "V" after diode mode reading.

Something damaged on <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>; diode mode reading is too low.
However not so low to use voltage injection.
You can remove SMC aand check the value again.
If still low, something else is the culprit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message:
Get SMC from 00138 board.
The one from 00163 may cause video issues.

BTW, did you check what I said above?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message:
Many chips connected there, not easy job.
Inspect <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>/50, <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7001</CHIP>, <CHIP>U4650</CHIP>, <CHIP>U4850</CHIP>, <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, J5250, J6100 for coorosion.
If nothing strange, then remove one by one and check diode mode reading each time.

Also take a look at filter caps placed on <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message: I removed <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and the value rose to 0.109 and he is the culprit

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message:
The board works now?
When board is cooled down, usual value is approx 0.300 at <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.message: Here I am! So I reballed to SMC now I get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3</SIGNAL> and 3v42, it starts for 5 seconds and then stops. So for 3 times, and I have orange light even with the battery not connected

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message:
Did you try SMC bypass?
Get known good battery for test in normal way; these boards may have weird issues without battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message: Does it work there is the dong there is no backlight but OS X charge is it the spi rom?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message:
Is not BIOS problem.
If board stays on in SMC bypass, must a problem with some I/V sensor.
Check first if <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> is present.

Remember to use 85W Magsafe 2 charger!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message: <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> is present

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message:
Start the board in SMC bypass mode and check all I/VSENSE outputs from page 44.
Post their levels here.

I'm not sure about what you mean with L7095.

If board stays on, check what I've said.
Start with <CAPACITOR>C5414</CAPACITOR>/21/41.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message:
Is normal to lose green light on SMC bypass mode.
But fans should start with full speed.

Do you get again low resistance to ground at L7095?
Post the exact value in diode mode (red to ground).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message: Did you use 00138 SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message: Correct

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message:
What is exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> w/ and w/o battery connected?
Of course, charger must be always connected.

If not good, check voltage and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message: Same voltage with and without connected battery 12.57

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light
threads.message:
First be sure battery is good, or test with known good one.
If still the same, change <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
Solder another SMC as last option.

threads.message: When it enters the operational theme if it tells me that the battery has 86 cycles, can it also depend on a bad welding of the SMC?
